title: How to Calculate Stability of a Model Rocket

steps.headline: Find the center of gravity of the rocket.
steps.description: This is the point at which you can balance the rocket on your finger.

steps.headline: Tie a four to six foot string around the rocket at this point.
steps.description: When hung from the string, the rocket should be parallel to the ground.

steps.headline: With the rocket suspended by the string, spin in a circle.
steps.description: If the rocket is stable, it will point forward in the direction you're turning.

steps.headline: Adjust the rocket to make it stable.
steps.description: There are two ways to do this. Move the center of gravity forward by adding weight to the nose. Move the center of pressure to the rear by enlarging or adding more fins.

text: Find the center of gravity of the rocket. This is the point at which you can balance the rocket on your finger. Tie a four to six foot string around the rocket at this point. When hung from the string, the rocket should be parallel to the ground. With the rocket suspended by the string, spin in a circle. If the rocket is stable, it will point forward in the direction you're turning. Adjust the rocket to make it stable. There are two ways to do this. Move the center of gravity forward by adding weight to the nose. Move the center of pressure to the rear by enlarging or adding more fins.
sentences: Find the center of gravity of the rocket.
This is the point at which you can balance the rocket on your finger.
Tie a four to six foot string around the rocket at this point.
When hung from the string, the rocket should be parallel to the ground.
With the rocket suspended by the string, spin in a circle.
If the rocket is stable, it will point forward in the direction you're turning.
Adjust the rocket to make it stable.
There are two ways to do this.
Move the center of gravity forward by adding weight to the nose.
Move the center of pressure to the rear by enlarging or adding more fins.
